summary: A video wryly debunking the myth that scientists in the 1970s collectively foresaw a coming ice age, contrasting popular myths with scientific consensus.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a suit and tie standing against a yellow background, holding a book and reading from it. The scene transitions to the same man, now against a blue background, still holding the book and reading. He then stands with his hands open, as if gesturing or emphasizing a point. The man continues to speak, holding the book in one hand and gesturing with the other. The video then shifts to a promotional image for "Penn & Teller: Bullshit!" featuring two men in suits posing with a large red ampersand symbol. The text "Penn & Teller: Bullshit!" is prominently displayed in bold red letters, indicating the title of the show or event being promoted. The background is white, and the overall atmosphere is professional and promotional.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with an urgent male voice warning "now we're going to pay for it". He cites scientists who are allegedly saying "we're heading into a new ice age". He proceeds to reference a Time Magazine article from "Monday, June 24th, 1974". This shifts into a measured, documentary-like male voice that says, "Yes, to quote the title of Penn and Teller's TV series, this video and the next will look at bullshit, or to put it more politely, urban myths, that have grown up around the subject of climate change". The tone is informative.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a promotional image for "Penn & Teller: Bullshit!" featuring two men in suits posing with a large red ampersand symbol. The scene transitions to a document titled "Secular and Solar Variability Input during Solar Cycle 23," discussing solar activity and its effects on Earth's climate. A quote on a dark background states, "30 years ago scientists said we were headed for another ice age." The video then shows a man in a suit and tie speaking on Fox News, followed by a newspaper article with a map titled "Areas of the Earth Affected by Climatic Change," highlighting regions impacted by climate change. The final frame features a man in a suit and tie speaking at a podium, with a quote from George Will in the Washington Post, dated May 22, 2008, referencing a New York Times article from August 14, 1975, about Earth heading towards another ice age. The video presents a narrative on climate change, historical predictions, and expert opinions.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing climate change and amateur research, contrasting it with expert research from previous videos. The speaker's tone is informative and conversational. He mentions Penn and Teller's "bullshit" and notes similar claims in internet blogs and mainstream media. He goes on to cite claims in Time Magazine in 1975, Senator James Inhoff, George Will citing the New York Times, and Michael Crichtonâ€™s book "State of Fear."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a book cover titled "State of Fear" by Michael Crichton, featuring a dramatic image of a lightning bolt striking through dark clouds. The scene transitions to a man in a suit and tie, standing against a blue background, holding a newspaper and speaking. The focus then shifts to a close-up of a magazine cover with the headline "What's Next?" and an image of a woman's eye magnified through a lens. The video then displays a newspaper article with the headline "Expanding Arctic," accompanied by a map of the Arctic region. The article discusses the expansion of the Arctic ice cap and its implications. The video concludes with a return to the book cover, emphasizing the title and author's name, reinforcing the theme of fear and impending danger.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing 1970s climate science, stating that "all the climate scientists believed an ice age was coming." He dismisses popular news sources as unreliable compared to scientific journals. Another male voice then objects, citing "Time magazine." The first speaker counters that Time is not peer-reviewed and prone to misreporting, urging the listener to "read the story" and identify the source of the ice age claim.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a newspaper article discussing climate change and its potential impact on the world's population. The article mentions the opinions of various climatologists and scientists, including Kenneth Hare and Donald Gilman, who express concerns about the sustainability of the current population and the possibility of another ice age. The text is in English, and the article is accompanied by a map in the background, which appears to be related to the topic of climate change. The video then transitions to a series of frames that zoom in on specific parts of the article, highlighting key phrases and sentences. The text is in English, and the phrases are emphasized with bold and enlarged fonts, making them stand out against the rest of the article. The video concludes with a close-up of the phrase "Climatological Cassandras are becoming increasingly apprehensive," which is highlighted in bold and enlarged text, emphasizing the growing concern among scientists about the potential consequences of climate change. The background remains consistent throughout the video, with the newspaper article and map providing context for the discussion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip consists primarily of a male speaker discussing a story about scientists who believed the earth was cooling, but one of whom did not believe an ice age was coming. He questions why the magazine that published the story had to resort to unnamed sources to get its information. The speaker has a measured and slightly critical tone. Intermittently, there's the sound of static crackling faintly in the background.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a close-up of a newspaper article discussing climate change, specifically mentioning "Climatological Cassandras" and the potential for another ice age. The text highlights the persistence of pack ice around Iceland and the southward migration of a weather pattern. The scene then transitions to a man in a suit and tie standing against a blue background, holding a piece of paper and gesturing as he speaks. The man appears to be delivering a presentation or lecture, possibly related to the topic of climate change discussed in the newspaper article. The video maintains a focus on the man's speech and gestures, emphasizing the importance of the subject matter.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker poses a question about "climatologists in the 1970s" and their acceptance of a "coming ice age." He then suggests that searching through "Time and Newsweek" is not the best way to find out. The speaker has a neutral and informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a suit standing against a blue background, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The scene transitions to a quote on a dark background, reading: "Our knowledge of the mechanisms of climatic change is at least as fragmentary as our data... not only are the basic scientific questions largely unanswered, but in many cases we do not yet know enough to pose the key questions." This quote is attributed to "Understanding Climate Change: A Program for Action," National Academy of Sciences 1975. The video then shifts to a lively dance scene, featuring a man in a white suit and a woman in a red dress dancing together. The man raises his arm triumphantly, while the woman looks on with a smile. The background is filled with sparkling lights, creating a festive atmosphere. The video captures the energy and movement of the dancers, highlighting their expressions and the dynamic environment around them.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker. Speaking in a factual tone, he introduces the need to look at scientific literature, noting an admission of "great uncertainty about the climate in the 1970s." He then questions if there was any consensus, mentioning predictions of "another ice age." The speaker continues by suggesting that if most scientists predicted an ice age, there should be scientific papers to support it, drawing a contrast to the abundance of papers supporting "anthropogenic climate change."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a scene of two individuals dancing energetically, one dressed in a white suit and the other in a long red dress, set against a backdrop of a crowd and a stage, suggesting a lively performance or event. The scene then transitions to a series of text-based slides, displaying a list of names and years, likely referencing historical events or significant figures in a particular field. The text is presented in a structured format, with years listed alongside names, indicating a chronological or thematic organization. The video then shifts to a visual representation of atmospheric gases, with chemical formulas such as N-N, O-O, H-O-H, and CH4 displayed against a backdrop of a landscape and sky, symbolizing the composition of the atmosphere. The final frames depict a clear blue sky with scattered yellow particles, possibly representing pollutants or particulate matter, emphasizing the environmental theme. The video combines dynamic human activity, historical references, and scientific visuals to convey a narrative that spans cultural, historical, and environmental contexts.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker delivering factual information in a neutral tone, referencing a study from the "Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society" that analyzed scientific literature. The speaker elaborates on the study, indicating that three climatologists found seven papers predicting global cooling but a greater number of articles predicting global warming. The speaker continues, giving reasons for the climate predictions and that climatologists suspected, and we now know, that the cooling was caused by pollution.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a series of frames displaying a computer screen filled with rows of text and data, likely representing a spreadsheet or database. The text is in a foreign language, with some words highlighted in different colors, possibly indicating different categories or statuses. The background of the screen shows a blurred image of a cityscape, suggesting that the computer is placed in an urban environment. The focus then shifts to a close-up of a magazine cover featuring a historical photograph of a motorcade, with the text "LIFE" prominently displayed at the top. The cover image shows a crowd of people, some of whom are waving, and a black car with a person inside, likely a figure of significance. The magazine is being broadcast on Fox News, as indicated by the logo in the bottom left corner of the screen. The text at the bottom of the screen reads "SOURCE: LIFE MAGAZINE," providing context for the image being shown. The video transitions from a technical display of data to a historical moment captured in a magazine cover, creating a contrast between the modern digital world and historical events.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker discusses climate change, mentioning that "global warming caused by carbon dioxide" would eventually "overwhelm any global cooling caused by pollution." He then questions why the media reported scientists predicting "global cooling." This is followed by a sound of something slamming.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a scene from a magazine cover featuring a group of people in formal attire, including a man in a suit and a woman in a dress, standing in front of a black car. The magazine is titled "LIFE," and the cover is displayed on a screen with the "FOX NEWS" logo in the bottom left corner. The scene transitions to a black screen with yellow text that reads, "World's temperature likely to rise" from "The Times, June 22 1976." The video then shifts to a man in a suit and tie standing against a black background, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The man appears to be emphasizing a point, with his fingers pointing upwards. The video maintains a focus on the man's gestures and expressions, suggesting he is delivering an important message or presentation. The overall atmosphere is serious and professional, with the man's attire and the dark background contributing to the formal tone of the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a conversational exchange between what appears to be one speaker followed by another, seemingly disagreeing with a prior assertion about the simplicity of the news in the 1970s. The second speaker mentions, "they weren't," followed by additional statements. The same male speaker continues to speak with a slight tone of disappointment.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing a suit and tie is seen standing against a dark background, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. He appears to be addressing an audience, possibly at a conference or public speaking event. The man is wearing glasses and has short, light-colored hair. As he speaks, a quote appears on the screen, attributed to George Will from the Washington Post, dated May 22, 2008. The quote reads: "The New York Times, Aug. 14, 1975, reported 'many signs' that 'Earth may be heading for another ice age.'" This quote is presented in white text against the dark background, making it stand out prominently. The man's facial expression and body language suggest that he is emphasizing the importance of the topic he is discussing, which seems to be related to climate change and environmental concerns. The overall atmosphere of the video is serious and focused, with the man's gestures and the quote on the screen reinforcing the gravity of the subject matter.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with one male speaker inquiring "How do I know?" before referencing a "1975 New York Times story." The speaker then describes a George Will column from the previous year, stating that it "reported many signs that Earth may be heading for another Ice Age." The speaker speaks in an informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man in a suit and tie, standing against a dark background, gesturing with his hands as he speaks. The text on the screen reads, "The New York Times, Aug. 14, 1975, reported many signs that 'Earth may be heading for another ice age.'" The man appears to be discussing the topic of climate change and its potential impact on the Earth's future. The scene then transitions to a series of newspaper articles discussing scientific findings and predictions about climate change. The articles are written in a formal, journalistic style, with bold headings and subheadings. The text is in English, and the articles are discussing the cooling trend in the Northern Hemisphere and the warming trend in the Southern Hemisphere, as well as the effects of carbon dioxide on the climate. The video then returns to the man in the suit, who continues to speak and gesture, with the text on the screen reading, "Chicken Littles: The Persistence of Eco-Pessimism" - Washington Post, May 31, 1992. The man appears to be discussing the persistence of eco-pessimism and the ongoing debate about climate change. The video concludes with the man still speaking, with the text on the screen reading, "many signs pointing to the possibility that the Earth may be heading for another ice age" (The New York Times, Aug. 14, 1975). The man appears to be summarizing the main points of his discussion, emphasizing the potential for another ice age and the need for continued research and discussion on the topic.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker recounting a story about tracking down an article, "Warming Trends Seen in Climate", and being surprised that it contradicted a claim made by George Will about an impending ice age. He mentions finding not one but three columns in which Will made the claim, specifically mentioning 1992, 2004, and last year. The speaker has a slightly conversational and anecdotal tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black screen, followed by the logo of the National Science Board (NSB), established in 1950, featuring the letters "NSB" in blue and the full name of the organization below it. The scene transitions to a document dated July 28, 2003, discussing the responsibilities of the Committee on Environment and Public Works, emphasizing the importance of relying on objective science and considering the impact on businesses, consumers, and the bureaucracy. The document critiques the concept of global warming, describing it as a "sheer lunacy" and comparing it to the "war of the 20th century." It quotes a statement from the record of past interglacial ages, suggesting that the present time of high temperatures should be ending, leading into the next glacial age. The quote is repeated in subsequent frames, with the final frame adding the phrase "20,000 years from now" in red text, emphasizing the timeline of the next glacial age. The video maintains a formal and informative tone throughout, focusing on the text and its implications.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Senator Inhofe's use of a quote, highlighting that it originated from a scientific body, rather than the popular media. The speaker proceeds to share Inhofe's quote from a 1974 report by the National Science Board: "Judging from the record of the past interglacial ages, the present time of high temperatures should be drawing to an end, leading into the next glacial age." The speaker then notes that Inhofe omitted the phrase "20,000 years from now" from the original report, which is similar to the 16,000-year estimate for the next ice age. The speaker's tone is informative and analytical.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a static image with a quote displayed in black and red text on a white background. The quote reads: "Judging from the record of the past interglacial ages, the present time of high temperatures should be drawing to an end...leading into the next glacial age 20,000 years from now." The text is centered and presented in a clear, legible font. The background is plain and devoid of any additional visual elements or distractions. The quote discusses the cyclical nature of Earth's climate, suggesting that the current warm period will eventually transition into a colder glacial age in the distant future. The video maintains this single image throughout, emphasizing the message conveyed by the text without any changes or additional visual information.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker is discussing an urban myth and its propagation, stating "for the purposes of propagating an urban myth." His tone is analytical and measured. He refers to a claim about "a consensus on an imminent ice age" as something that "does the rounds unchecked," even when disguised as science.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man and a woman seated in a studio setting, engaged in a conversation. The man, dressed in a dark suit and tie, gestures with his hands while speaking, and the woman, wearing a black outfit, listens attentively, holding a notepad. The background features a cityscape with illuminated buildings, suggesting a nighttime setting. The scene transitions to a close-up of a book cover titled "State of Fear" by Michael Crichton, with a dramatic image of lightning striking a dark, cloudy sky. The video then shifts to an aerial view of a large, deep canyon, showcasing its rugged terrain and vast expanse. Following this, a man in a suit is seen speaking at a podium, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. The video concludes with a return to the studio setting, where the man and woman continue their discussion, with the man now holding a microphone and the woman still holding her notepad. Throughout the video, the atmosphere is professional and focused, with the studio setting providing a consistent backdrop for the conversation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with an introduction to Headline Earth, promising to explain global warming. A female speaker mentions a trend or scare of "global cooling" in the 1970s. A male speaker takes over, asserting there was no scientific consensus about the climate in the 1960s, only a realization that the climate was changing. He continues, criticizing that climatologists have got the "global warming thing wrong" and that they predicted global cooling in the 1970s. The male speaker then asks what kind of individual would want to manufacture misleading information to discredit them.
